website_content.content:
Editor's Note: Former President Donald Trump's took the stage around 1 p.m. This video will be updated as it becomes available. 
Protests and traffic are expected in downtown Chicago Wednesday as former President Donald Trump will be in town to speak at an event as part of the National Association of Black Journalists convention. 
📺 24/7 Chicago news stream: Watch NBC 5 free wherever you are
The potential traffic disruption comes as road closures for this weekend's Lollapalooza music festival in Chicago are also set to go into effect 
Trump is scheduled to appear at the convention, taking place at the Hilton Hotel at 720 S. Michigan Ave., at 12 p.m. Wednesday as part of a conversation with moderators Rachel Scott of ABC News; Harris Faulkner of Fox News and Kadia Goba Semafor, a post from the NABJ said. 
The event, open to convention attendees only, is described by organizers as a "Q&A with political journalists before an audience of registered convention attendees that will concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community." It will be fact-checked live by PolitiFact, and is scheduled to last one hour, organizers said.
No questions from the audience will be taken, the event website said. It will be streamed live in the player above and on the NBC Chicago streaming channel once it begins.
“We look forward to our attendees hearing from former President Trump on the critical issues our members and their audiences care about most,”...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: NBC Chicago is part of the NBC News network, which is a reputable national news outlet. It has a history of covering local, national, and international news accurately. NBC News is known for professional journalism standards and has proven to be reliable in reporting events with appropriate context. They also perform checks on news items to prevent the spread of misinformation, although no news source is perfect.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence mentions upcoming protests against Donald Trump in Chicago but does not specifically reference any light displays or mention the sentiment of Trump Tower residents. It is relevant in the context of protests against Trump in Chicago but does not provide substantial information directly about Trump Tower residents' protests or light displays.

Analysis & Opinions \- Vox
Media Coverage Has Blown Anti-lockdown Protests Out of Proportion
=================================================================
Authors:*   
*   Lara Putnam
*   Tommy Leung
*   
*   Nathan Perkins
| May 10, 2020
Recent anti-Trump rallies have been bigger than the anti-lockdown protests. Guess which ones got more media attention?
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In the last few weeks, protests against state lockdowns and social distancing measures have  headlines. The wall-to-wall coverage might give the impression that what we're seeing is a powerful grassroots movement in the making.
But research we just conducted on protest attendance and media coverage shows something different: This massive media coverage has in fact been out of proportion.
A comprehensive look at the social distancing protests reveals that they have been small in terms of both the number of participants and locations. As one official in the administration of Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan (R)  about a protest in Annapolis on April 20, "There were more media inquiries about this than there were participants."
Our count confirms this impression. As of May 3, we counted 245 protests throughout  and early  against social distancing and related restrictions. In contrast, notable recent uprisings numbered in the hundreds of protests throughout the country in a single day, including Lights for Liberty against the detention of immigrants on July 12, 2019 (699), the climate strikes of September 20, 2019 (1184), pro-impeachment rallies on December 17, 2019 (599), and the fourth Women’s March on January 18 of this year (267).
The social distancing protests have also drawn modest crowds, with between 35,000 and 47,000 total attendees reported across all events combined through May 3. In comparison, a...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs at Harvard University conducts research and provides policy solutions related to international security. As an academic institution, it emphasizes research-backed reports and discussions. However, it is more of a think tank than a traditional news outlet; thus, while it provides valuable analysis, it may not always cover current events as news media do.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence discusses anti-Trump rallies and their media coverage but does not focus on Trump Tower residents nor light displays. It indicates a broader context of protests related to Trump but lacks specific instances pertinent to the Claim and the question about media representation of protests by Trump Tower residents.

Government websites can provide official information, but their scope is generally limited to statutory functions and may lack broader journalistic rigor. Their reliability for news reporting may vary based on the information provided, thus a middle ground score is warranted.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence is a report on Chicago's response to protests and unrest, but it does not mention Trump Tower residents or any light displays. Its content is largely unrelated to the specific question, making it minimally relevant.

Trump audited for double-dipping tax breaks on Chicago’s Trump Tower
====================================================================
ProPublica and the New York Times found the former president could end up owing the IRS more than $100 million for claiming the same massive losses twice on his namesake River North tower.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
By  
  !
Hundreds of protesters marched in front of Trump Tower on June 13, 2020, after the murder of George Floyd by police officer Derek Chauvin sparked protests across the nation.
Pat Nabong/Sun-Times
*   
*   
Share
CLOSE
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
Former President Donald Trump could be hit with a bill of more than $100 million for claiming improper tax breaks on his namesake tower along the Chicago River, according to a report Saturday by ProPublica and The New York Times.
In a yearslong audit battle, the IRS has contended that Trump effectively wrote off the same massive losses twice on the Trump International Hotel and Tower at 401 N. Wabash Ave., 
Trump reported $651 million in losses on the River North tower in 2008, when he claimed the 92-story building met the tax code definition of “worthless” shortly before its completion during the heart of the Great Recession, the news outlets found.
Then, in 2010, Trump shifted the company that owned the tower into a new partnership, a move he cited to justify $168 million in additional losses over the next 10 years, ProPublica and...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The Chicago Sun-Times is a longstanding newspaper in Chicago with a reputation for local reporting. While it has faced challenges in maintaining journalistic quality over the years, it generally provides reliable news stories. They have investigative journalism capabilities and often cover political issues thoroughly, making it a credible source for Chicago-related news.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This article mentions protests in front of Trump Tower but does not specifically address light displays or the sentiments of the residents therein. It provides some context about residents interacting with the tower, but not in a way that directly supports the Claim or answers the question adequately.

metatags.pagetitle: Watching the watchdogs: How US media weaponised campus protests coverage

website_content.content:
Mainstream media has joined US power elites in demonising pro-Palestinian encampments on campuses.
A great, novel experiment in political physics is under way in the United States, as the unstoppable moral force of youth-led protests against Israel’s genocidal war in Gaza runs into the immovable object of the American power elite’s support for it.
In this clash, two critical forces have been weaponised: the US mainstream media that heavily disseminates Israeli propaganda and shapes many local, state and national policies, and the scourge of anti-Semitism that has been unfairly used to demonise and silence Palestinians and shift attention away from the US-enabled Israeli genocide in Gaza.
Since Israel launched its assault on Gaza, President Joe Biden’s steadfast support for it has galvanised young Americans and pushed them to mobilise.
They have formed decisive coalitions with Muslim and Arab Americans, Jewish, Black, Hispanic and Native communities, labour unions and churches. They have given notice that if the US continues to support the war, they will abandon Democratic candidates in the November elections, which would likely be fatal for the party.
The American power elite largely ignored the initial criticisms of the young and the marginalised, until student encampments started springing up at universities across the country three weeks ago. The students demanded an immediate ceasefire in Gaza...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Al Jazeera has gained international recognition as a news outlet that covers various global issues. Although its coverage may sometimes be seen as biased due to its Qatari ownership, it is generally regarded as a reliable source of news outside of the U.S. It provides comprehensive reporting on issues that other outlets may overlook, and it has robust journalism standards, hence a higher quality score.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This article discusses media coverage of campus protests and does not relate to Trump Tower residents or light displays at all. It is entirely irrelevant to the question posed.

While it can provide valuable insights and coverage of marginalized communities, its independent nature may lack the fact-checking resources of larger outlets, which may affect reliability. It has a unique voice in the media landscape, but its reporting may be less conventional, leading to a moderate score.

It gives context to the sentiment against Trump but lacks direct information about what residents themselves did to symbolize their disdain, including any use of lights.

Medill students receive Society of Professional Journalists awards
==================================================================
Mark of Excellence awards honor collegiate journalism
-----------------------------------------------------
!
The Society of Professional Journalists presents the Mark of Excellence Awards annually. Offering 51 categories in print, radio, television and online publications, the awards honor the best in collegiate journalism. According to SPJ, MOE Awards entries are judged by professionals with at least three years of journalism experience.
The following students from Medill and Northwestern received awards this year in the Region 5 contest, which includes Illinois, Indiana and Kentucky:
*   Staff of The Daily Northwestern, Breaking News Reporting, _Reports of man with gun on campus determined to be hoax, “swatting incident”_
*   Julia Esparza (BSJ20), General News Reporting, _Salvadoran woman finds refuge in Evanston church, attempts to reunite with daughter_
*   Libby Berry (BSJ19), General News Reporting, _Lawmakers in last-minute push to make members of Congress liable for sexual harassment_
*   Jane Recker (BSJ19) and Marissa Martinez (BSJ21), General Column Writing
*   Benjamin Rosenberg (BSJ21), Sports Writing, _NU grad earns fellowship with MLB commissioner, hopes to become league’s first female GM_
*   Editorial Board of The Daily Northwestern, Editorial Writing
*   Staff of The Daily Northwestern, Best All-Around Daily Student Newspaper
*   Elizabeth Guthrie (BSJ20), Non...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: This site belongs to Medill, the journalism school at Northwestern University. It provides education, training, and research on journalism practices. While not a traditional news outlet, it contributes to the field of journalism and can provide academically rigorous analysis on media trends and practices. However, its primary function is educational rather than news reporting.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This is irrelevant as it discusses journalism awards rather than any protests or light displays related to Trump Tower residents or their sentiments.

#### 
‘He’s Not Welcome Here’: Protesters Tell Trump He Isn’t Wanted in Chicago Ahead of Former President’s Appearance
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 | July 31, 2024 2:36 pm
")
!Protesters gathered outside Hilton Chicago, where former president Donald Trump was set to speak Wednesday, July 31, 2024. (Matt Masterson / WTTW News)
As Donald Trump took the stage Wednesday to speak inside Hilton Chicago, protesters gathered outside and decried the former president as a “racist” and “weirdo.”
Thanks to our sponsors:
-----------------------
---------------------------------------------------
A few dozen protesters gathered outside the hotel Wednesday morning where they said Trump was not welcome in Chicago ahead of his appearance at the National Association of Black Journalists’ annual convention. Trump spoke in a conversation moderated by three journalists.
“Racist Trump, the racist Republican Party, the reactionary policies, the fascist policies and their candidate are just not welcome in this city,” Hatem Abudayyeh, chair of the Chicago-based U.S. Palestinian Community Network told WTTW News. “The vast majority of Chicagoans feel that way, the vast majority of people in the United States feel that way as well. That’s why we’re here.”
Wednesday’s event marked Trump’s second appearance in Chicago since 2016, when massive protests forced him to scrap a rally on the University of Illinois Chicago campus. His NABJ convention speaking event was only announced this week.
The hastily assembled protest Wednesday along South Michigan Avenue remained peaceful as attendees chanted “Racist, sexist, anti-gay, Donald Trump go away” and “Say it loud, say it clear, Donald Trump’s not welcome here.”
A six-piece brass band also sang “Trump’s not like us” to the tune of Kendrick Lamar’s “Not Like Us.”
Chicago police blocked off side streets near the hotel, but traffic continued unabated along Michigan Avenue.
The rally included several speakers who protested Trump and his presidential campaign during the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee earlier this month and plan to organize again for the Democratic National Convention next month in Chicago.
Among them was Kobi Guillory, an activist with the Chicago Alliance Against Racist and Political Repression, who said Trump should not be given a platform to speak in Chicago.
“Every time he’s making his racist points, what city does he use to make his racist talking points? Chicago, this city right here,” Guillory said....[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: As mentioned previously, WTTW’s news component conducts reputable local reporting and focuses on providing a rigorous standard of journalism.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence pertains to protests against Trump in Chicago and outlines sentiments expressed during these demonstrations. While it does not mention light displays directly, it indicates an organized protest atmosphere, which could imply various forms of expression that might include lights. However, it does not provide specific evidence of light displays by Trump Tower residents.
